text:
JAKE TAPPER: Hey,
everybody is Jake

Tapper from CNN's "State of
the Union" and factcheck.org.

And this week we're going
to take a look at comments
made by Dr. Tom Price.

He is the Secretary
of the Department
of Health and Human Services.

He spoke with NBC on March
12 about the health care plan

that the House Republican
leadership and the Trump
administration is pushing.
Take a listen.
TOM PRICE: I-- I--

I firmly believe that-- that
nobody will be worse off

financially in
the-- in the process

that we're going through,
understanding that they'll have

choices that they can
select the kind of coverage

that they want for themselves
and for their family,

not that government
forces them to buy.

So there's cost that
needs to come down,

and we believe we're
going to be able to do
that through this system.

There's coverage
that's going to go up.

JAKE TAPPER: So Dr. Price said
that he firmly believes nobody
will be worse off financially.

And obviously we can't fact
check what he believes.

But in terms of
whether or not it's

true that nobody will be
worse off financially,
that's not true.

There are going to
be winners and losers

in this Republican
health care bill,

just as there were winners
and losers in Obamacare.

Let's start off with
who will do better

under this Republican plan
as it is drafted right now.
One, young Americans.

They could get
some cheaper plans.
Two, healthy people.

They'll have the
option of buying

less expensive
catastrophic plans, which

have much lower monthly
premiums, theoretically,
and much higher deductibles.

Also, of course, wealthy
Americans and insurance
companies will get big tax cuts.

But obviously, there are
going to be losers as well.

According to the nonpartisan
Congressional Budget office,

in 10 years, by 2026, there will
be 24 million or more Americans

who are uninsured under
this Republican plan

than there otherwise
would have been.

This includes, according to CBO,
14 million low-income Americans

who would have benefited
from Medicaid by 2026,

plus an additional
2 million Americans

who will no longer
get health insurance
on the individual market.

Some Americans will choose
not to have insurance,

but others will find
themselves no longer able
to afford health insurance.

The CBO also expects
the number of people

with employer-based insurance
to drop by 7 million

on net, partly because fewer
employees would take up

the offer of health insurance
without an individual mandate,

and partly because,
quote, "over time,

fewer employers
would offer health
insurance to their workers."

Now another group
that could lose

out under this plan,
older Americans,
those between 50 and 64.

That's because the new
Republican plan gets
rid of the Obamacare mandates.

And one of the Obamacare
mandates is that insurance

companies cannot
charge older Americans

any more than three
times more than
they charge younger Americans.

But that cap will
be disposed of.

Take a look at what the CBO says
about the Republican proposal.

Quote, "Under this legislation,
premiums for older people

could be five times larger
than those for younger
people in many states.

But the size of the tax
credits for older people

would only be twice
the size of the credits
for younger people."

This is one of the reasons
why the AARP came out
against the Republican's plan.

The bill, according
to CBO, will also

adversely impact people in
areas with high insurance costs.

That's because the Republican
plan's tax credits structure

will no longer take into account
the variation in insurance
costs based on geography.
Here's the bottom line.

The Republican health care
plan being debated right now

will have some winners
and some losers, just

like every other
health care plan.

So for anyone to
promise you that no one

will be worse off
financially because of it,
that's just not true.

A reminder to all you
politicians out there,

you're perfectly entitled
to your own opinions,
not to your own facts.

I'm Jake Tapper for CNN's
"State of the Union"
and factcheck.org.
[music playing]
